comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Are those roofing slates in the foreground?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Yes, they're probably Liscannor Stone which is quarried in the surrounding area. This was shipped by the quarries from Liscannor pier which is how the stone got the name.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 57099931@N05
comment._content:
Liscannor Stone was most famous as flooring and paving. Killaloe slate was used for roofing.
The streets of London were paved with Liscannor Stone. Also on very low tide you can see the hull of a ship laden with similar slabs half buried in the sand.

comment.author: 87247922@N00
comment._content: Liscannor stone was used for roofing some buildings around the area, there is one building in Lahinch which still has the big stones on the roof - the Cetlic T-shirt Shop.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The building with the sign on the right is a Smithy according to the Os 25 " map.
